dict.string: Use this section to define settings for FileVault 2

In macOS 10.9, you can use FileVault 2 to perform full XTS-AES 128 encryption on the contents of a volume. FileVault 2 payloads are designated by specifying com.apple.MCX.FileVault2 as the PayloadType value. Removal of the FileVault payload does not disable FileVault.
Optional. A human-readable description of this payload. This description is shown on the Detail screen.
A human-readable name for the profile payload. This name is displayed on the Detail screen. It does not have to be unique.
A unique identifier for the payload, dot-delimited. Usually root PayloadIdentifier+subidentifier.
A reverse-DNS-style identifier for the specific payload. It is usually the same identifier as the root-level PayloadIdentifier value with an additional component appended.
The type of the payload, a reverse dns string.
A globally unique identifier for the payload. The actual content is unimportant, but it must be globally unique. In macOS, you can use uuidgen to generate reasonable UUIDs.
The version of the whole configuration profile.

The version number of the individual payload. A profile can consist of payloads with different version numbers. For example, changes to the VPN software in iOS might introduce a new payload version to support additional features, but Mail payload versions would not necessarily change in the same release.
This value describes the issuing organization of the profile, as displayed to the user.

Optional. A human-readable string containing the name of the organization that provided the profile. The payload organization for a payload need not match the payload organization in the enclosing profile.
Set to 'On' to enable FileVault. Set to 'Off' to disable FileVault.
Set to ʼOnʼ to enable FileVault. Set to ʼOffʼ to disable FileVault. This value is required.
Defer enabling FileVault until the designated user logs out. For details, see fdesetup(8). The person enabling FileVault must be either a local user or a mobile account user.
Set to true to defer enabling FileVault until the designated user logs out. For details, see fdesetup(8). The person enabling FileVault must be either a local user or a mobile account user.
Set to true for manual profile installs to prompt for missing user name or password fields.
Set to true for manual profile installs to prompt for missing user name or password fields.
Set to true to create a personal recovery key.
Set to true to create a personal recovery key. Defaults to true.
Set to false to not display the personal recovery key to the user after FileVault is enabled.
Set to false to not display the personal recovery key to the user after FileVault is enabled. Defaults to true.
Path to the location where the recovery key and computer information plist will be stored.
Path to the location where the recovery key and computer information plist will be stored.
DER-encoded certificate data if an institutional recovery key will be added.
DER-encoded certificate data if an institutional recovery key will be added.
UUID of the payload containing the asymmetric recovery key certificate payload.
UUID of the payload containing the asymmetric recovery key certificate payload.
User name of the Open Directory user that will be added to FileVault.
User name of the Open Directory user that will be added to FileVault.
User password of the Open Directory user that will be added to FileVault. Use the UserEntersMissingInfo key if you want to prompt for this information.
User password of the Open Directory user that will be added to FileVault. Use the UserEntersMissingInfo key if you want to prompt for this information.

If set to true and no certificate information is provided in this payload, the keychain already created at /Library/Keychains/FileVaultMaster.keychain will be used when the institutional recovery key is added.

If set to true and no certificate information is provided in this payload, the keychain already created at /Library/Keychains/FileVaultMaster.keychain will be used when the institutional recovery key is added.
Add institutional recovery key to keychain

When using the Defer option you can optionally set this key to the maximum number of times the user can bypass enabling FileVault before it will require that it be enabled before the user can log in. If set to 0, it will always prompt to enable FileVault until it is enabled, though it will allow you to bypass enabling it. Setting this key to –1 will disable this feature.

When using the Defer option you can optionally set this key to the maximum number of times the user can bypass enabling FileVault before it will require that it be enabled before the user can log in. If set to 0, it will always prompt to enable FileVault until it is enabled, though it will allow you to bypass enabling it. Setting this key to –1 will disable this feature. Availability: Available in macOS 10.10 and later.
Maximum number of times FileVault can be skipped
When using the Defer option, set this key to true to not request enabling FileVault at user logout time.
When using the Defer option, set this key to true to not request enabling FileVault at user logout time. Availability: Available in macOS 10.10 and later.
